para.paratext: Sound recordings are admissible in evidence with a proper foundation.[1]
O.C.G.A. § 24-9-923 provides in part as follows:

(b) Subject to any other valid objection, photographs, motion pictures, video recordings, and audio recordings shall be admissible in evidence when necessitated by the unavailability of a witness who can provide personal authentication and when the court determines, based on competent evidence presented to the court, that such items tend to show reliably the fact or facts for which the items are offered.

(c) Subject to any other valid objection, photographs, motion pictures, video recordings, and audio recordings produced at a time when the device producing the items was not being operated by an individual person or was not under the personal control or in the presence of an individual operator shall be admissible in evidence when the court determines, based on competent evidence presented to the court, that such items tend to show reliably the fact or facts for which the items are offered, provided that, prior to the admission of such evidence, the date and time of such photograph, motion picture, or video recording shall be contained on such evidence, and such date and time shall be shown to have been made contemporaneously with the events depicted in such photograph, motion picture, or video recording.

(d) This Code section shall not be the exclusive method of introduction into evidence of photographs, motion pictures, video recordings, and audio recordings but shall be supplementary to any other law and lawful methods existing in this state.

In Steve M. Solomon, Jr., Inc. v. Edgar,[2] the Georgia Court of Appeals formulated an elaborate set of requirements for authenticating a sound recording. The proponent of this type evidence must show (1) that the mechanical transcription device was capable of taking testimony, (2) that the operator of the device was competent, (3) the authenticity and correctness of the recording, (4) that changes, additions, or deletions have not been made, (5) the manner of preservation of the record, (6) the identification of the speakers, and (7) that the testimony elicited was freely and voluntarily made. Federal courts do not require this much foundational detail.[3]

The Georgia Supreme Court specifically adopted the rule of the Solomon case in Central of Georgia R. Co. v. Collins[4] and extended it to recordings of sounds other than the human voice. In that action to enjoin a nuisance, the plaintiff sought to admit a cassette recording made by the plaintiff's wife of the noise of a railroad car weighing operation. Acknowledging that this was a question of first impression in Georgia, the court held that there was no reason not to admit a sound recording of something other than the human voice and slightly varied the requirements established in Solomon by substituting the following: that the device must be capable of taking “noise of the type attempted to be recorded” for “testimony.” Additionally, the court recognized that requiring the proponent to identify the speakers and show that they spoke freely, without duress, would be irrelevant in a noise transcription.[5]

Two years later in Harris v. State,[6] the court upheld the admission of a sound recording, which contained fewer foundational details than those required by Solomon, and noted that not all of the requirements of Solomon were necessary due to advances in the area since that decision.
In subsequent decades, the court vacillated between the strict foundational requirements of Solomon and the more relaxed foundational requirements of Harris.[7]

In Henley v. State,[8] the Georgia Supreme Court stated that former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-48 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-9-923) creates a method for authenticating a voice recording when an authenticating witness is “unavailable.” The court held that there was sufficient evidence to establish the reliability of a tape of a voicemail message for purposes of authentication because the voicemail message was purportedly from the defendant and left on the voicemail service of the victim's brother; the brother testified that he had known the defendant for approximately two years and recognized his voice on the message and that he knew from long experience with the voicemail service that it accurately recorded messages; and the state entered into evidence phone records showing that a call placed from the defendant's cell phone number to the brother's cell phone number went to voicemail at the relevant time.[9] In Jones v. State,[10] a recorded telephone conversation made from jail was admissible where an investigator testified as to the defendant's voice. Likewise, in Carter v. State,[11] the Georgia Supreme Court permitted brief recordings of random conversations made by the defendant where it allowed the jury to compare the defendant's voice.

Where sound recordings are received in evidence, a transcript of the recording may be substituted in the record. The jury is permitted to have transcripts of the tapes while listening to the sound recording tapes, but the transcripts should not be permitted to go to the jury room for their consideration.[12]

Steve M. Solomon, Jr., Inc. v. Edgar, 92 Ga. App. 207, 88 S.E.2d 167 (1955); State v. Williams, 49 Wash. 2d 354, 301 P.2d 769 (1956); Brooks v. State, 141 Ga. App. 725, 234 S.E.2d 541 (1977); Williams v. State, 142 Ga. App. 764, 236 S.E.2d 893 (1977); Allen v. State, 146 Ga. App. 815, 247 S.E.2d 540 (1978) (holding modified by, State v. Berky, 214 Ga. App. 174, 447 S.E.2d 147 (1994)); Taylor v. State, 149 Ga. App. 30, 253 S.E.2d 428 (1979) (tapes were properly authenticated under the Solomon test).
Brooks v. State was approved in Page v. State, 249 Ga. 648, 292 S.E.2d 850 (1982).
Goodwin v. State, 154 Ga. App. 46, 267 S.E.2d 488 (1980), held that the test of the Solomon case did not apply where a detective repeated a conversation he overheard from a “body bug” on a decoy.

In Wheeler v. Aiken, 154 Ga. App. 280, 267 S.E.2d 883 (1980), a recording expert had prepared tapes from the original tapes, reducing the background noise. The court held that no proper foundation had been laid under the test of the Solomon case.

Tapes were properly authenticated in Howell v. State, 167 Ga. App. 294, 306 S.E.2d 378 (1983); King v. State, 168 Ga. App. 291, 308 S.E.2d 612 (1983); Hall v. State, 176 Ga. App. 428, 336 S.E.2d 291 (1985).
Admissibility of sound recordings as evidence in federal criminal trial, 10 L. Ed. 2d 1169; Agnor, The Use of Sound Recordings before Courts-Martial, 8 Wayne L. Rev. 299 (1962).
Central of Georgia R. Co. v. Collins, 232 Ga. 790, 209 S.E.2d 1 (1974).
Central of Georgia R. Co. v. Collins, 232 Ga. 790, 209 S.E.2d 1 (1974).
Harris v. State, 237 Ga. 718, 230 S.E.2d 1 (1976).
The Harris case was followed in Stanley v. State, 240 Ga. 341, 241 S.E.2d 173 (1977); Thomas v. State, 240 Ga. 393, 242 S.E.2d 1 (1977); Smith v. State, 171 Ga. App. 758, 321 S.E.2d 213 (1984).
However, in Palmer v. State, 158 Ga. App. 743, 282 S.E.2d 201 (1981), and in Ellis v. State, 164 Ga. App. 366, 296 S.E.2d 726 (1982), the Solomon test was applied.

In Simmons v. State, 174 Ga. App. 171, 329 S.E.2d 312 (1985), the defendant requested a charge that the jury must find compliance with the Solomon test. This request was properly refused as the Solomon test deals only with the admissibility of the tape and that is a matter for the judge alone.

In Galaxy Carpet Mills, Inc. v. Massengill, 255 Ga. 360, 338 S.E.2d 428 (1986), tape recordings of boiler noise were admissible under Central of Georgia R. Co. v. Collins, but the court did not require the full test set out in Steve M. Solomon, Jr., Inc. v. Edgar.
Elliott v. State, 168 Ga. App. 781, 310 S.E.2d 758 (1983); Kelley v. State, 168 Ga. App. 911, 311 S.E.2d 180 (1983); Lawrence v. State, 174 Ga. App. 788, 331 S.E.2d 600 (1985).

In Gaston v. State, 180 Ga. App. 470, 349 S.E.2d 526 (1986), the jury had copies of the transcript of the tape while it was being played and the transcripts were admitted in evidence. Nothing appears in the case as to whether or not the transcripts went out with the jury.
See Carey v. State, 257 Ga. 134, 356 S.E.2d 507 (1987).
